Fig. 1 Effect of W loading amount of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst on the reaction of 1,2-OcD. Reaction conditions: WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 0−30 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) 75 mg, 1,2-octanediol 6.8 mmol, 1,4-dioxane 4 g, H2 8 MPa, 453 K, 16 h. a Pd/TiO2 (Pd 2.9 wt%). OE = dioctyl ether, OcOH = octanol, 1 = 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane (adduct of octanal and 1,2-octanediol), 2 = octyl 2-hydroxyoctyl ether, 3 = 2-octyloxy-1-octanol, 4 = 1,2-bis(octyloxy)octane. Detailed data are shown in Table S1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of Pd loading amount of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst on the reaction of 1,2-OcD. Reaction conditions: WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0−0.75) 75 mg, 1,2-octanediol 6.8 mmol, 1,4-dioxane 4 g, H2 8 MPa, 453 K, 16 h. OE = dioctyl ether, OcOH = octanol, 1 = 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane (adduct of octanal and 1,2-octanediol), 2 = octyl 2-hydroxyoctyl ether, 3 = 2-octyloxy-1-octanol, 4 = 1,2-bis(octyloxy)octane. Detailed data are shown in Table S2. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Time course of 1,2-OcD reduction over WOx-Pd/TiO2. Reaction conditions: WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) 75 mg, 1,2-octanediol 6.8 mmol, 1,4-dioxane 4 g, H2 8 MPa, 453 K. OE = dioctyl ether, OcOH = octanol, 1 = 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane (adduct of octanal and 1,2-octanediol), 2 = octyl 2-hydroxyoctyl ether, 3 = 2-octyloxy-1-octanol, 4 = 1,2-bis(octyloxy)octane. Detailed data are shown in Table S3. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of catalyst amount on 1,2-OcD reduction. Reaction conditions: WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) 10−150 mg, 1,2-octanediol 6.8 mmol, 1,4-dioxane 4 g, H2 8 MPa, 453 K, 16 h. OE = dioctyl ether, OcOH = octanol, 1 = 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane (adduct of octanal and 1,2-octanediol), 2 = octyl 2-hydroxyoctyl ether, 3 = 2-octyloxy-1-octanol, 4 = 1,2-bis(octyloxy)octane. Dashed lines represent the selectivity change to intermediate compounds. Detailed data are shown in Table S4. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Proposed reaction route from 1,2-octanediol (1,2-OcD) to dioctyl ether (OE) over WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XRD patterns of WOx-Pd/TiO2 (Pd/W = 0.25) catalysts after calcination (a-f) and after use (g). (a) W 4 wt%, (b) W 8 wt%, (c) W 12 wt%, (d) W 16 wt%, (e) W 20 wt%, (f) W 30 wt%, (g) W 20 wt%, after use. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TPR profiles of WOx-Pd/TiO2 (Pd/W = 0.25) and monometallic catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 W L 3-edge XANES spectra. a: W foil, b: WO2, c: WO3, d: Na2WO4, e: WOx/TiO2, f: WOx-Pd/TiO2 (after calcination), g: WOx-Pd/TiO2(after reduction), h: WOx-Pd/TiO2(after one use), i: WOx-Pd/TiO2 (after four uses; calcined at 673 K between uses). W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25 for WOx-Pd/TiO2. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Raman spectra of catalysts after calcination. Pd/W = 0.25 for WOx-Pd/TiO2. Department of Applied Chemistry School of Engineering Tohoku University 6-6-07 Aoba Aramaki, Aoba-ku Sendai 980-8579 Japan Graphical abstract Direct synthesis of dioctyl ether by catalytic reduction of 1,2-octanediol (1,2-OcD) was investigated with various supported catalysts containing W and noble metals. The combination of rutile TiO2 support and Pd with W showed the highest yield of dioctyl ether, up to ca. 45 % (carbon-based). The catalytic activity much depended on the W loading amount, and the amount corresponded to monolayer coverage or more was necessary to obtain good yield. The data at low conversion levels showed that the reaction started with WOx/TiO2-catalyzed dehydration of 1,2-OcD to octanal, which then reacted with 1,2-OcD to give acetal. The stepwise hydrogenolysis of the acetal gave dioctyl ether. The WOx-Pd/TiO2 was significantly deactivated during uses, and the deactivated catalyst even lost the activity in 1,2-OcD dehydration. The characterization results of the used catalyst were not much different from the fresh one with XRD, Raman, NH3-TPD, IR of adsorbed pyridine and XAFS techniques. Metastable minor site on WOx/TiO2 was probably responsible to the catalytic activity. Keywords Ether Tungsten Rutile titania Dehydration Hydrodeoxygenation Introduction Importance of hydrodeoxygenation, which typically uses acid + metal bifunctional catalysts, has been increasing recently, because of the necessity of replacing fossil fuel with biomass which has high oxygen content, for example sugars and sugar alcohols [1–7]. In order to minimize the consumption of hydrogen, selective partial hydrodeoxygenation to target product is superior to the combination of total hydrodeoxygenation and reoxidation. Various types of hydrodeoxygenation catalysts with different selectivity should be developed, depending on the types of target products. One important family of target products is dialkyl ethers, which can be used as fuel additives since they have low freezing points and good cetane number (in the case of linear ethers) and the addition to fuel suppresses the soot formation [8–10]. One of typical manufacture methods of linear dialkyl ethers is intermolecular dehydration of primary alcohols over acid catalysts such as sulfonic acids [11–14], zeolites [15] and acidic metal oxides [16–18]. While the main current production methods of primary alcohols are fermentation [19,20], carboxylic acid/ester hydrogenation [21–23] and hydrogenation of hydroformylation product of alkenes [24–26], the production of primary alcohols by hydrodeoxygenation of poly-functionalized compounds is possible with several systems. Typical such hydrodeoxygenation systems use bimetallic catalysts in water solvent, such as Rh-ReOx [27] and Pt-WOx catalysts [28–30] which are known to be also effective for selective hydrodeoxygenation of several other biomass-derived molecules [31–37]. However, direct production of ethers from polyfunctionalized compounds by hydrodeoxygenation has been rarely reported. Schlaf et al. reported hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-propanediol with Ru complex catalyst, TfOH co-catalyst and sulfolane solvent into 1-propanol and dipropyl ether in 54 % and 16 %-C yield, respectively [38,39]. In this study, we used 1,2-octanediol (1,2-OcD) as a model substrate for the development of catalyst for the one-pot production of dialkyl ether (dioctyl ether (OE) from 1,2-OcD) from diol by hydrodeoxygenation (eq. (1)). We explored the catalysts among supported bimetallic catalysts composed of noble metal and W because WOx species are known to have both acidity and modification effect of noble metal catalysts [27–37,40–42]. WOx-Pd/rutile TiO2 catalyst was found to be the effective one, and the catalyst structure as well as the reaction route will be discussed. (1) Experimental Catalyst preparation The bimetallic catalysts were prepared by sequential impregnation method. First, support material was impregnated with aqueous (NH4)6[H2W12O40] (Aldrich) solution at 353−363 K. After the water solvent was vaporized, the sample was further dried at 383 K overnight. Next, the dried sample was impregnated with aqueous solution of noble metal precursor at 353−363 K. The sample was dried at 383 K overnight and then calcined at 773 K for 3 h. The used supports were rutile TiO2 (Catalysis Society of Japan JRC-TIO-16; BET surface area 93 m2 g−1), anatase TiO2 (Wako; 11 m2 g−1), SiO2 (Fuji Silysia G-6; pre-calcined at 973 K for 1 h; 535 m2 g−1), ZrO2 (Daiichi Kigenso RC-100 P; pre-calcined at 1273 K for 1 h; 10 m2 g−1), CeO2 (Daiichi Kigenso HS; pre-calcined at 873 K for 3 h; 84 m2 g−1), γ-Al2O3 (Aerosil; pre-calcined at 973 K for 1 h; 100 m2 g−1) and MgO (Ube 500A; pre-calcined at 973 K for 1 h; 38 m2 g−1). The used noble metal precursors were Pd(NO3)2 (N.E. Chemcat), H2PtCl6 (Aldrich), Ru(NO)(NO3)3-x(OH)x (Aldrich), Ir(NO3)4 (Furuya metal), and RhCl3 (Wako). Typical catalysts had 20 wt% W loading and noble metal/W molar ratio 0.25. Hydrodeoxygenation reactions The activity tests were carried out in an autoclave reactor with inner volume of 190 mL. Substrate, catalyst, solvent (1,4-dioxane) and a stirrer tip were added to a glass inner vessel which was then set to the autoclave reactor. After purging the air with H2, the autoclave was pressurized with H2. The H2 amount was controlled to the level that the pressure became the appropriate value (typically 8 MPa) when the reactor was heated to the reaction temperature (453 K). The heating took about 1 h. The reaction time started to count when the temperature of the reactor became 2 K below the set temperature. The temperature was controlled ±2 K during the reaction. After the appropriate reaction time, the reactor was quickly cooled with water. Both gas and liquid phases were collected and analyzed. The gas phase sample was analyzed with FID-GC equipped with Rtx-PONA column. The liquid phase, which was combined with additional solvent for washing the reactor, was analyzed with FID-GC equipped with TC-WAX column. The products were identified with GC–MS with both EI and CI modes. The details of MS data of commercially-unavailable intermediates are described in Supplementary Material (Fig. S1). Conversion was determined by the decrease of substrate; however, in the cases with very low conversion (<10 %), conversion was determined by the ratio of the sum of products to the sum of products and remaining substrate because the experimental error for the decrease of substrate was large. Selectivity was determined by the ratio of the amount of carbon atoms in the product to the sum of the total carbon amount in all the products, i.e. carbon-based selectivity. The carbon balance was 100 ± 10 % in most runs, although when the intermediate compounds or other unidentified compounds were formed in large amount the error in the carbon balance was sometime larger (maximum 12 %). For the reuse tests, the used catalyst was collected by centrifugation (6000 rpm, 5 min), washed with 1,4-dioxane by dispersion and centrifugation, and dried at 383 K overnight. The dried collected catalyst was used for the next run, or used after removal of organic deposit by calcination at 673 K for 1 h. The leached amount of Pd and W was measured by ICP-AES (ThermoFisher iCAP6500). After the reaction test, the reactor was opened in a glove bag filled with N2. The reaction mixture was collected, and the reactor was washed with 1,4-dioxane. The reaction mixture and the washing solvent was mixed, and the catalyst was removed by filtration. The filtrate was analyzed by ICP-AES. Catalyst characterization XRD patterns were obtained with Rigaku MiniFlex 600 diffractometer under air. TEM images were taken with Hitachi HD-2700. Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) profiles were obtained with home-made apparatus composed of quartz glass tube reactor with 4 mm inner diameter, frozen acetone trap and TCD. The sample (100 mg) was reduced with flowing 5% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) during heating from room temperature to 1273 K at heating rate of 10 K min−1. Raman spectra were measured with JASCO NRS-5100 instrument under air. The sample was excited with 532 nm laser for 60 s. TG-DTA profile was obtained with Rigaku Thermo Plus EVO-II instrument. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was carried out with MicrotracBEL BELCAT-II instrument equipped with BELMass mass spectrometer. The sample (50 mg) was first treated with He at 773 K for 1 h and then cooled to 323 K. Ammonia (5% in He) was introduced for 30 min. After purging gas-phase ammonia with He for 15 min, the sample was heated under He flow (30 ml min−1) at 10 K min−1 rate, and the effluent gas was analyzed with mass spectrometer. FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine was measured with Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. Sample (85 mg) was pressed into 20 mmφ self-supported wafer and set in an in situ cell with CaF2 windows. The sample was heated at 673 K for 1 h under Ar (50 mL/min) to remove adsorbed impurities, and then it was reduced with flowing H2 (30 mL/min) for 1 h at 453 K. After purging H2 with Ar, the spectrum of the catalyst as the background was measured at 423 K. Pyridine (0.2 μL) was injected into the cell under flowing Ar (50 mL/min) at 423 K. The spectrum was accumulated 10 min after the injection of pyridine. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurement was carried out at BL14B2 (proposal No. 2019A1825) and BL01B1 (proposal No. 2019B1325) stations of SPring-8. The reduced or used catalysts were packed and measured under N2 atmosphere to avoid the exposure to air. The data were collected in a transmission mode for reference compounds and non-used catalysts. The edge jumps for the catalyst samples were 0.4−0.8. The data for used catalysts were collected in a fluorescence mode, and the edge jumps were about 0.1. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra were obtained by subtraction of a modified Victoreen equation and normalization with the edge height. For extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), the oscillation was first extracted using a spline smoothing method, and Fourier transformation was applied to k 3-weighted oscillation. The empirical phase shift and amplitude functions for Pd-Pd bond and WO bond in the curve fitting analysis was extracted from the EXAFS spectrum of Pd foil and Na2WO4, respectively. The data processing of both XANES and EXAFS was performed with REX2000 ver. 2.6.0 program (Rigaku). Results and discussion Catalyst screening The reaction results over various bimetallic catalysts containing W are summarized in Table 1 . WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst using rutile TiO2 support showed by far the best dioctyl ether (OE) yield (Entry 1). WOx-Pd catalysts on other supports (Entries 2–7) showed much lower conversion, indicating the specific effect of rutile TiO2 support. These results contrast with the reported results for 1,4-anhydroerythritol reduction to 3-hydroxytetrahydrofuran over WOx-Pd/support catalysts where the support effect including TiO2 was not large [42]. The reaction mechanism for 1,2-OcD reduction over WOx-Pd/TiO2 can be different from that of 1,4-anhydroerythritol reduction, which was proposed by us to be the combination of deoxydehydration and hydration [42]. Without a noble metal (WOx/TiO2, Entry 8), the conversion of 1,2-OcD was still high; even much higher than those over all the WOx-Pd catalysts on non-TiO2 supports. The main product over WOx/TiO2 was the acetal-type adduct of octanal and 1,2-OcD (compound 1), indicating that the overall reaction over WOx-Pd/TiO2 starts with the dehydration of 1,2-OcD to octanal over WOx/TiO2. In the literature, WOx/TiO2 catalyzed dehydration of simple alcohols (mono-ols) to alkenes has been well investigated [43–49]. However, most studies used anatase-type TiO2 or anatase-rich anatase-rutile mixture TiO2 (P-25) as support, and WOx/anatase has been considered to have higher activity than WOx/rutile [46,49]. On the other hand, in our case, WOx-Pd/anatase (Entry 7) showed much lower conversion activity of 1,2-OcD than WOx-Pd/TiO2 and WOx/TiO2. Here, the surface W concentration (ratio of W loading amount to surface area) and total W amount in the reaction system were adjusted to those of standard WOx-Pd/rutile-TiO2 catalyst system. Because the used anatase support had very small surface area, the used amount of WOx-Pd/anatase catalyst in Entry 7 was very large. We also carried out a reaction test with lower amount of WOx-Pd/anatase and the result was compared with the results of WOx-Pd/rutile TiO2 with similar W amount in the system (Fig. S2). In addition, we further prepared another WOx-Pd/rutile TiO2 with very small surface area and the reaction result was also compared. The results showed that WOx-Pd/rutile TiO2 with different surface areas showed comparable activity when the amount of W in the reaction mixture was similar, while WOx-Pd/anatase TiO2 had much lower activity. Rutile TiO2 as support seems to be crucial in this reaction. The reaction mechanism of 1,2-OcD dehydration might be different from that of mono-ol dehydration to alkenes where WOx/anatase TiO2 has been reported to be active. The effect of noble metal (M) in WOx-M/TiO2 catalysts was further investigated (Entries 9–12). The conversion of 1,2-OcD was high over all these catalysts, which agrees with the idea that the first step of the reaction was the dehydration of 1,2-OcD over WOx/TiO2. The main product was different: 1-octanol (1-OcOH) became the main product when M = Pt, Ru and Ir, and both 1-octanol and n-octane were the main products when M = Rh. These results can be explained by the much higher activity of Pt, Ru, Ir and Rh in hydrogenation of aldehydes than Pd [50–52] and the high activity of Rh catalyst modified with reducible oxide (MoOx, ReOx and WOx) in C-O hydrogenolysis of alcohols [27,31,33]. Formation of compound 1 from octanal and 1,2-OcD is reversible, and octanal can be readily hydrogenated to 1-OcOH over these noble metals. C-O hydrogenolysis of 1-OcOH to n-octane can proceed over WOx-Rh catalyst. After all, WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst with rutile structure of TiO2 support is specifically effective in OE formation from 1,2-OcD. The other detected products include ethers of 1,2-OcD and 1-OcOH (compounds 2, 3 and 4). The detailed reaction route over WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst will be discussed later. The effect of W loading amount in WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst on the 1,2-OcD reaction is shown in Fig. 1 (detailed data: Table S1). The conversion of 1,2-OcD remained low until W loading amount =8 wt%. The conversion increased suddenly above this W loading amount, and the complete conversion was obtained at W 16 wt% and 20 wt% catalysts. The conversion slightly decreased when W loading amount was further increased to 30 wt%. The highest yield of OE or sum of OE and n-octane, which is a potential overreaction product of OE, was highest at 20 wt% W loading, indicating that 20 wt% W loading gives the highest activity. It is well known that the structure and catalytic activity of supported WOx species much depends on the W loading amount per surface area (surface W concentration), and the monolayer coverage is frequently the key state. The monolayer coverage of WOx/TiO2(anatase) has been reported to be 4.5–4.9 W atoms/nm2 [43–49], which corresponds to 11−12 wt% W on TiO2 with 93 m2/g surface area, although the value may be slightly different because the structure type was different in our case (rutile). The W loading amount above the monolayer level is effective in this reaction. The effect of Pd loading amount is shown in Fig. 2 (detailed data: Table S2). As described above, without Pd, no reduction products were detected and the main product was the adduct of octanal and 1,2-OcD. The presence of small amount of Pd in the catalyst led to the formation of reduction products, such as OE, n-octane, 1-OcOH and ethers of 1-OcOH and 1,2-OcD. The formation amounts of more deeply reduced products (OE, n-octane and 1-OcOH) increased with the increase of Pd amount up to Pd/W = 0.25 (mol/mol). The conversion of 1,2-OcD also increased. Above the Pd amount, the formation amount of n-octane increased and those of OE and 1-OcOH gradually decreased. After all, the optimized loading amount was W 20 wt% and Pd/W = 0.25 (mol/mol). Reaction progress over WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst The time course of the reaction of 1,2-OcD over the optimized catalyst, WOx-Pd/TiO2 (20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25), is shown in Fig. 3 (detailed data: Table S3). The highest yield of OE was obtained at 16 h, which is the standard reaction time used for the data shown above. The change of product distribution after 16 h was very slow: The amount of ethers of 1-OcOH and 1,2-OcD (compounds 2-4) and that of 1-OcOH slightly decreased, and that of n-octane slightly increased. The amount of OE was hardly changed. The conversion of 1,2-OcD was almost 100 % even at short reaction time (1 h). The OE formation amount reached about half of the final yield at 1 h, while the total yield of ethers of 1-OcOH and 1,2-OcD (compounds 2-4), which are possible intermediates of OE, was about 50 %. The adduct of octanal and 1,2-OcD (acetal 1), which was the main product when Pd was absent, was hardly detected during all the reaction times (1−72 h). Next, we carried out reaction experiments using lower amount of catalyst in order to obtain the reaction results at lower conversion levels. Surprisingly, we found that the dependence on the catalyst amount was much different from that on the reaction time. Fig. 4 shows the effect of catalyst amount on 1,2-OcD reaction at the standard reaction time (16 h). The detailed data are shown in Table S4. Lowering the catalyst amount much decreased the 1,2-OcD conversion, while shortening the reaction time from 16 h to 1 h did not decrease the 1,2-OcD conversion from >99 % (Fig. 3). These different trends were probably due to the deactivation of catalyst during the reaction: when the catalyst amount was small, the reaction stopped before the total conversion of 1,2-OcD. Nevertheless, we obtained the reaction results at different conversion levels, and the reaction route can be discussed. At low conversion level (27 %; catalyst amount 10 mg) the main product was the adduct of octanal and 1,2-OcD (acetal 1). This result agreed with the idea that WOx/TiO2-catalyzed dehydration of 1,2-OcD to octanal is the first step of the reaction, which is suggested by the reaction over Pd-free WOx/TiO2 catalyst. The target product OE was not present at this conversion level, indicating that OE was not directly produced from 1,2-OcD. Increasing the conversion level to ca. 50 % (catalyst amount 25 mg) much decreased the selectivity to 1, and those of 1-OcOH and mono-ethers of 1-OcOH and 1,2-OcD (2 and 3) much increased. They can be produced from 1, via hydrogenation of reversibly formed octanal from 1 (1-OcOH) or C-O hydrogenolysis of 1 (2 and 3). The target product OE began to be formed, although the selectivity was still low (3%). An important point is that the two monoethers 2 and 3 were formed in almost 1:1 ratio. Both 2 and 3 should be considered as important intermediates. With further increase of the conversion (80 % and 97 %; catalyst amount 37.5 mg and 50 mg, respectively) 1 was almost totally consumed and the selectivity to 2 and 3 began to decrease. The selectivity to OE increased, and the diether of 1-OcOH and 1,2-OcD (compound 4) began to be formed in significant amount. The diether 4 was probably formed from 2 and/or 3, and OE was probably also mainly produced via formation of 2 and/or 3. At total conversion of 1,2-OcD (catalyst amount 75 and 150 mg), the selectivity to 4 began to decrease. Because 2-octyloxyoctane was not formed, the product from 4 was OE. The OE yield was hardly changed from the run with catalyst amount 75 mg–150 mg, indicating that the overreaction of OE was much slower. The low reactivity of OE was also suggested by the time course of the reaction (Fig. 3); however, the slow reaction of OE in Fig. 3 might be due to the deactivation of catalyst. The low reactivity of OE was confirmed by the result of excess amount of catalyst in Fig. 4. The highest yield of OE (46.5 %) was obtained with larger amount of catalyst (150 mg), while the highest TON (molar ratio of OE to W) was obtained at standard reaction conditions (75 mg; TON = 19) with almost the same OE yield (45.2 %) as the highest value. The reaction of octanols (1-OcOH and 2-OcOH) and OE was tested with WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst in order to further discuss the reaction route from 1,2-OcD, and the results are shown in Table 2 . In the case of the reaction of 1-OcOH (Table 2, Entry 2), the conversion was much lower than the case of the reaction of 1,2-OcD, and the main products were OE and n-octane with almost 1:1 selectivity ratio. In order to check whether OE formation was limited by equilibrium or not, the remaining amounts of OE and 1-octanol were compared between the reactions of 1,2-OcD (Entry 1) and 1-OcOH (Entry 2). In the case of the reaction of 1,2-OcD, OE and 1-OcOH amounts after reaction were 45 %-C and 22 %-C of total carbon of the system, respectively. In the case of the reaction of 1-OcOH, OE and 1-OcOH amounts after reaction were 26 %-C and 49 %-C of total carbon. The amount of formed water was also compared, because the water concentration in the system also affects the equilibrium. The formation of OE, 1-OcOH and n-octane from 1,2-OcD was accompanied with 1.5 equiv., 1 equiv. and 2 equiv. of water formation, respectively (eqs. (2)–(4)). (2) C6H13CHOHCH2OH + H2 → 1/2 C8H17OC8H17 + 3/2 H2O (3) C6H13CHOHCH2OH + H2 → C8H17OH + H2O (4) C6H13CHOHCH2OH + 2 H2 → C8H18 + 2 H2O On the other hand, the formation of OE and n-octane from 1-OcOH was accompanied with 0.5 equiv. and 1 equiv, of water formation, respectively (eqs. (5) and (6)). (5) C8H17OH → 1/2 C8H17OC8H17 + 1/2 H2O (6) C8H17OH + H2 → C8H18 + H2O Based on eqs. (2)–(6), the formed water amount in the reactions of 1,2-OcD (Entry 1) and 1-OcOH (Entry 2) was calculated to be 1.3 equiv. and 0.4 equiv. of substrate, respectively. Smaller amount of water is preferable to OE formation in view of equilibrium. However, in the reaction of 1-OcOH, the OE/1-OcOH ratio after reaction was lower than that after reaction of 1,2-OcD, which was contrary to the equilibrium control. This indicates that the reaction of 1-OcOH to OE in Entry 2 was not limited by the equilibrium. Therefore, the reactivity of 1-OcOH over WOx-Pd/TiO2 was lower than 1,2-OcD. On the other, hand, the reactivity of 2-OcOH was high (almost total conversion), and n-octane was formed with high selectivity (99 %) (Table 2, Entry 3). The WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst can efficiently cleave the COH bond in secondary alcohols. The higher reactivity of 2-OcOH than 1-OcOH can be explained by the higher reactivity of secondary alcohols toward dehydration by acid-catalyzed E1 mechanism. The reactivity of ether (OE) was very low (Entry 4), which agreed with the previous results with larger catalyst amount. Based on the all data, the reaction route of 1,2-OcD reduction over WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst is proposed as shown in Fig. 5 . First, 1,2-OcD is dehydrated to form octanal, which then reversibly reacts with 1,2-OcD to give acetal 1. CO hydrogenolysis of 1 gives two types of ethers: 2-octyloxy-1-octanol (2) and 2-hydroxyoctyl octyl ether (3). The strength of the two CO bonds of the octanal unit in 1 is similar, and the formation amount ratio of 2:3 was near 1. The ether 2 has reactive secondary COH and it is then converted into OE by the removal of the OH group. The other ether 3 was converted to diether 4 by the reaction of the primary COH with 1-OcOH which is formed by hydrogenation of octanal or CO hydrogenolysis of the secondary COR of 3. The diether 4 is converted to OE by CO hydrogenolysis of the secondary C-OR. The higher reactivity of secondary C-OR than primary COR (R = C8H17) is presumed by the higher reactivity of 2-OcOH than 1-OcOH (R = H). 1-OcOH is converted to n-octane or OE. Although 1-OcOH is also consumed during the formation of diether 4 from monoether 3, the 1-OcOH is released again during the formation of OE from 4. n-Octane was formed in a similar amount to OE in the reaction of 1-OcOH. Assuming that the formation ratio of OE: n-octane from 1-OcOH intermediate in the reaction of 1,2-OcD was the same as the case of the reaction of 1-OcOH as the substrate, about half amount of OE was estimated to be formed via 1-OcOH intermediate, and the other half of OE was formed via ether 2 or diether 4. Therefore, the suppression of 1-OcOH formation is a key to high OE yield. While most steps in Fig. 5 are catalyzed or co-catalyzed by acid, 1-OcOH formation by CO hydrogenation of octanal is catalyzed by metal. The selection of metal with low CO hydrogenation activity is important. Pd is known to be a less active metal in CO hydrogenation than the other noble metals [50–52]. In fact, WOx-M/TiO2 catalyst with another noble metal as M showed higher selectivity to 1-OcOH and n-octane than the case of M = Pd (Table 1). The deactivation of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst during the reaction was suggested by the difference between the time course (Fig. 3) and the dependence on the catalyst amount (Fig. 4). Here, the deactivation behavior was investigated by the reuse tests. The results of the reuse tests are shown in Table 3 . When the catalyst after reaction was used only after washing and drying (Table 3, Entry 2), the activity was much decreased (76.2 % conversion (Entry 1) → 13.3 % conversion). The selectivity pattern of the second run was similar to that of the fresh catalyst with similar conversion level (Fig. 4, 10 mg catalyst-16 h), suggesting that the activity in almost all steps was decreased simultaneously. Next, the used catalyst was calcined at 673 K to remove the organic deposit that might cover the active site. The calcination temperature was determined based on the TG-DTA profile of the used catalyst (Fig. S3), where the weight decrease ended at about 673 K. The activity test of the calcined used catalyst showed that the calcination partially recovered the activity; however, the activity was still significantly lower than that of fresh catalyst. Further reuse-calcination cycles further decreased the activity, and in the third reuse the catalyst showed no conversion of 1,2-OcD (Entry 5). Because the 1,2-OcD conversion is due to the dehydration of 1,2-OcD catalyzed by WOx/TiO2, the activity of WOx/TiO2 was lost during reuses. The leaching amount into the reaction solution during the standard run (Table 1, Entry 1) was analyzed by ICP-AES. The detected amounts of both W and Pd were below the detection limit (<0.1 % of total amount in the catalyst), indicating that the leaching was negligible. Catalyst characterization Here, the WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalysts were characterized. Because both the W loading amount and the reuses much affected the activity, the catalysts with different W loading amounts as well as catalysts after use were characterized, and we will discuss the structure-performance relationship. While WOx/anatase TiO2 or WOx/TiO2 with anatase-rich mixture (P-25) has been intensively investigated in the literature as a strong acid catalyst [43–49], WOx/TiO2 with pure rutile structure has been much less investigated and not well characterized [49,53,54]. Fig. 6 shows the XRD pattern of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalysts with different W loadings and constant Pd/W ratio (0.25). All catalysts showed intense peaks of rutile TiO2 support, and no peaks for anatase (for example, 2θ = 25.4°) were observed. No peaks for W species were observed in the patterns of calcined catalysts with ≤12 wt% W loadings. Small peaks of WO3 were observed in the pattern of W 20 wt% catalyst, and the peak intensities were not changed after reaction. The intensities of WO3 peaks increased with increase of W loading to 30 wt%. The small peaks for Pd species were also observed in the patterns of catalysts with ≥16 wt% W loadings, as PdO (2θ = 34.6°; in calcined catalysts) or Pd metal (2θ = 40.1°; after reaction). As described above (Fig. 1), the catalysts showed the highest activity when the W loading amount was 16−20 wt%. Stronger intensities of WO3 peaks in W 30 wt% catalyst suggests that crystalline WO3 phase is not involved in the catalysis. The TEM images of WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) catalyst after reduction or reaction were taken; however, sharp images could not be obtained probably because of the presence of amorphous WOx species on TiO2 support (Fig. S4). Nevertheless, the image of the catalyst after reduction had small particles with about 3 nm, which might be the Pd particles. The TEM image after reaction was further blurred, probably because of the organic deposit as well as amorphous WOx species. The reducibility of W species in the catalysts was investigated. Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR profiles of catalysts. The Pd-free WOx/TiO2 (W 20 wt%) began to be reduced at around 600 K, and the main reduction signal was located above 700 K. In the Pd-added catalysts, the main signals of the reduction of W were hardly shifted. The result contrasted with many cases of bimetallic catalysts composed of noble metal and reducible metal oxide where the reducibility of metal oxide is significantly promoted by the noble metal [31], including WOx-Pd/C in our previous paper [42]. The H2 desorption peak (negative peak) from Pd metal was observed at 350 K, indicating the formation of Pd metal at further lower temperature. The temperature for catalytic reaction (453 K) was lower than the main TPR peaks for W reduction, suggesting that most of W species were not reduced in the reaction. For further investigation of the reduction degree of W species, we measured W L 3-edge XANES spectra (Fig. 8 ). The samples after reduction or reaction were packed under N2 atmosphere to avoid the change of oxidation degree by the contact with air. It is known that W L 3-edge spectra of high-valent W species have complex patterns with multiple white lines, and it is difficult to quantify the valence state [55]. Nevertheless, the patterns of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalysts after calcination, reduction at 453 K in liquid phase or catalytic use were almost the same as that of calcined WOx/TiO2. The similar spectra among calcined WOx-Pd/TiO2, reduced one and used one were also observed with EXAFS (Fig. S5 and Table S5). These behaviors indicate that most of W species in WOx-Pd/TiO2 were not changed during the catalytic reaction from the fully oxidized state (+6 valence state), which agrees with the TPR results. XAFS (XANES and EXAFS) analysis was also used for the characterization of Pd species. From Pd K-edge XANES spectra (Fig. S6), WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) samples after reduction (453 K with H2), after one catalytic use and after four catalytic uses all showed similar spectrum pattern to Pd foil, indicating the formation of metallic Pd phase. The EXAFS spectra of WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) samples after reduction (453 K with H2), after one catalytic use and after four catalytic uses could be fitted by one Pd-Pd shell (Table 4 and Fig. S7), which also indicates the formation of metallic Pd phase. The Pd-Pd coordination number in reduced WOx-Pd/TiO2 was significantly lower than that of bulk Pd (12), which means the formation of Pd nanoparticles, agreeing with the TEM result. The Pd-Pd coordination number in Pd/TiO2 was similar to that in WOx-Pd/TiO2, suggesting that WOx species did not affect the dispersion of Pd metal. The Pd-Pd coordination number of WOx-Pd/TiO2 almost unchanged after first catalytic use (8.7) and then slightly increased after four catalytic uses (9.4). Nevertheless, the coordination number values were significantly lower than that of bulk Pd (12). These data indicated that the Pd particles could slightly aggregate probably during the regeneration steps (calcination-reduction). Also considering the weak dependence of the performance on the Pd amount (Fig. 2), the loss of activity during reuse tests was not due to the aggregation of Pd. Fig. 9 shows the Raman spectra of catalysts. Raman spectroscopy is a frequently-used tool for the characterization of supported W catalysts because it provides the information of the coordination structure of oxide species. We measured catalyst samples after calcination, because the difference of reduction degree and the presence of organic deposit (for used catalysts) can complicate the Raman spectra. Pure rutile TiO2 support showed the peaks of 607 and 434 cm−1 which are assigned to A1g and Eg vibration modes, respectively, and the “baseline” broadly rose because of the second-order Raman scattering [56]. The anatase TiO2 is known to have the peaks of 640, 520 and 400 cm−1. The peak at 520 cm−1 was not observed for all samples, indicating that the formation of anatase phase was negligible. The two peaks for rutile TiO2 were not changed by loading WOx; however, when Pd was also loaded, the Eg peak (434 cm−1) of rutile TiO2 was significantly shifted to lower wavenumber. Similar shift of TiO2 peak by co-loading of W and Pd has been also reported for Pd-W/anatase TiO2 [57]. Several interpretations of the peak shift in Pd-W/anatase TiO2 have been proposed, including the induction of oxygen defect and the pressure effect due to the surface tension of grains [57]. On the other hand, in our case, both WOx/TiO2 without the peak shift and WOx-Pd/TiO2 with the peak shift showed activity in 1,2-OcD conversion. The structure change associated with the peak shift of TiO2 is not the main cause of the catalytic activity. The Raman bands for WO bond stretches are present in 700−1100 cm−1, and the peak positions depend on the structure of WOx species. The catalysts with ≥20 wt% W loading showed the Raman bands for bulk WO3 at 812 and 719 cm−1, and the results well agreed with the XRD data. The Pd-added catalysts with high loadings also showed small peak at 640 cm−1 assignable to PdO [58]. All catalysts except very low W loading showed peaks between the range 970−1010 cm−1, which are assigned to WO stretch of WOx cluster species including monolayer and polyoxotungstate species. The peak positions are known to be shifted to larger wavenumber with the increase of cluster size or with the coordination state change from octahedral to tetrahedral ones [59]. However, the structure-performance relationship was not clear in our case. The WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalysts with low W loading showed the WO peak at relatively lower wavenumber, and the peak was shifted to higher wavenumber with increase of W loading amount. The repeated catalytic uses shifted the peak to lower wavenumber. Considering the high activity of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalysts with high W loading and the low activity of reused catalyst, the W species with high wavenumber of WO Raman band (1008 cm−1) seems to have high activity. However, Pd-free WOx/TiO2 catalyst with significant activity in 1,2-OcD conversion had WO band at 971 cm−1, which wavenumber value was smaller than that of WO band of any Pd-added catalyst. The assignment of these WO Raman bands to specific structure is rather difficult. Nevertheless, based on the reported assignments of WOx/TiO2 (anatase or P-25) in both ambient and dehydrated conditions [59,60], we tentatively assigned the 971 and 1008 cm−1 bands as two-dimensional sheet composed of octahedral WOx species (monolayer WOx species) and tetrahedral WOx species produced by dehydration of the two-dimensional WOx sheet, respectively. Because the reaction of 1,2-OcD produces significant amount of water, the tetrahedral WOx species can be re-converted into octahedral species [59]. The loaded WOx species above the monolayer amount were mainly present as bulk WO3. Next, the acidity of WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst was investigated by NH3-TPD. Here, we measured the profiles of fresh and used WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%) catalysts. The used sample was calcined to remove the organic deposit, and the calcined catalysts were measured for comparison. As described above in Table 3, the activity of catalyst after one use and calcination was less than half activity of the fresh one, and the activity was totally lost during four uses. The TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 10 . The fresh WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst showed broad signals from weak acid sites (<523 K) to strong ones (>723 K). Similar NH3-TPD profile of WOx/rutile TiO2 showing the presence of strong acid sites has been also reported in the literature [53]. However, the calcined used catalyst with lower activity showed almost the same NH3-TPD profile. We also measured the FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine on WOx-Pd/TiO2 (Fig. S8). The used catalyst was also calcined to remove the organic deposit which may affect the IR spectrum. The spectra in the 1400−1700 cm−1 range were also almost the same between fresh and calcined used catalysts in views of peak position and the intensity ratio of Lewis/Brønsted acid sites (1540 cm−1/1450 cm−1). The major acidic WOx sites seem to be inactive in the 1,2-OcD conversion. Some metastable WOx species formed in small amount on as-prepared WOx/TiO2 seem to be active in 1,2-OcD dehydration or other dehydration reactions as key steps in C-O hydrogenolysis. Dehydration reactions over WOx/TiO2 using anatase TiO2 have been intensively investigated, and the reported activity typically corresponded to the amount of acid sites [43,45,47,49]. Only gradual deactivation because of the coke formation has been typically reported for WOx/anatase TiO2 [47,48]. These behaviors are much different from our case using rutile TiO2. Indeed, the deactivation behavior of WOx/rutile TiO2 has been rarely investigated in the literature. Elucidation of the structure of active sites formed on WO3/rutile TiO2 will be the next step of our study, which may lead to development of much more active catalysts for polyol dehydration or hydrogenolysis. Conclusions The combination of rutile TiO2 and Pd among various supports and noble metals with WOx is particularly effective in the one-pot reductive production of dioctyl ether (OE) from 1,2-octanediol (1,2-OcD). Other supports showed lower activity and higher selectivity to 1-octanol (1-OcOH), and other noble metals showed high selectivity to 1-OcOH although the activity is comparable to Pd. The turnover number based on W amount (OE/W molar ratio) reached 19 at 45 % OE yield using 1 g 1,2-OcD (6.8 mmol) and 75 mg WOx-Pd/TiO2 (W 20 wt%, Pd/W = 0.25) catalyst. The reaction started with WOx/TiO2-catalyzed dehydration of 1,2-OcD to octanal, which quickly reacted with 1,2-OcD to give acetal-type adduct 1. The acetal 1 was then converted to hydroxyethers (compounds 2 and 3) by C-O hydrogenolysis. Hydroxyethers were converted by further hydrogenolysis and/or etherification to give final product OE. These hydrogenolysis reactions probably proceeded via acid-catalyzed C-O dissociation and Pd-catalyzed hydrogenation. Hydrogenolysis of OE to n-octane was very slow over WOx-Pd/TiO2 catalyst. Another reaction route to OE was the intermolecular dehydration of 1-OcOH which can be produced by hydrogenation of octanal; however, n-octane is also produced when 1-OcOH is involved as an intermediate. High catalytic activity of other noble metals (M) than Pd in aldehyde hydrogenation is related to the high selectivity of WOx-M/TiO2 to 1-OcOH and n-octane rather than OE. The activity of WOx-Pd/TiO2 much depended on the W amount: The W loading slightly above the monolayer level was the best amount; the catalysts with lower W loading showed very low activity even considering the smaller W amount. However, the catalytic activity was much decreased during reuses, even when the recovered catalyst was calcined to remove the organic deposit. The acidic nature shown by NH3-TPD and IR of adsorbed pyridine was not changed after reaction, suggesting that metastable minor sites rather than the most observable acid sites were responsible to the catalytic activity in acid-catalyzed steps including 1,2-OcD dehydration. coredata.dc:description: Direct synthesis of dioctyl ether by catalytic reduction of 1,2-octanediol (1,2-OcD) was investigated with various supported catalysts containing W and noble metals. The combination of rutile TiO2 support and Pd with W showed the highest yield of dioctyl ether, up to ca. 45 % (carbon-based). The catalytic activity much depended on the W loading amount, and the amount corresponded to monolayer coverage or more was necessary to obtain good yield. The data at low conversion levels showed that the reaction started with WOx/TiO2-catalyzed dehydration of 1,2-OcD to octanal, which then reacted with 1,2-OcD to give acetal. The stepwise hydrogenolysis of the acetal gave dioctyl ether. The WOx-Pd/TiO2 was significantly deactivated during uses, and the deactivated catalyst even lost the activity in 1,2-OcD dehydration. The characterization results of the used catalyst were not much different from the fresh one with XRD, Raman, NH3-TPD, IR of adsorbed pyridine and XAFS techniques. Metastable minor site on WOx/TiO2 was probably responsible to the catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: One-pot production of dioctyl ether from 1,2-octanediol over rutile-titania-supported palladium-tungsten catalyst
